Introduction

Skeletal muscle function depends on the coordinated interaction of electrical, chemical, and mechanical processes.  At the core of this physiology is the excitation-contraction coupling mechanism, through which an action potential triggers calcium release and ultimately leads to muscle contraction.  Neuromuscular transmission, sarcolemmal excitability, and intracellular calcium dynamics are tightly integrated to ensure precise regulation of force generation.  Cardiac and smooth muscle, which contract involuntarily (unlike skeletal muscle), share some similarities with skeletal muscle but exhibit differences in structure and regulation.

Skeletal muscle structure



Skeletal muscle is composed of long, cylindrical multinucleated cells called muscle fibers, which are formed by the fusion of myoblasts during development.  Each muscle fiber is surrounded by a plasma membrane known as the sarcolemma and contains numerous myofibrils, which are the contractile elements of the cell.  Myofibrils are organized into repeating structural units called sarcomeres, giving skeletal muscle its characteristic striated appearance (

figure 1
).  These sarcomeres are aligned end-to-end along the length of the myofibril and serve as the fundamental unit of muscle contraction.



A sarcomere is composed of overlapping filaments of actin and myosin as well as structural and binding proteins (eg, titin, alpha-actinin).  A single sarcomere is defined as the distance between 2 Z lines.  Thin filaments (actin, tropomyosin, troponin) are bound to structural proteins at the Z line.  The unbound ends of the actin filaments project into the middle of the sarcomere, where they interact with thick filaments (myosin) during muscle contraction.  The organization of the filaments gives rise to distinct bands and lines that can be seen on electron microscopy (

image 1
):



  • The Z line (Z disc) defines the lateral boundaries of each sarcomere and is the anchoring point for thin filaments.  The Z line is typically darker than the remainder of the sarcomere.
  • The M line, where myosin filaments anchor to structural elements, lies in the center of the sarcomere.
  • The I band is the light region of the sarcomere in which actin does not overlap with myosin.
  • The A band corresponds to a dark region of myosin filaments in the sarcomere.  In this region, there are myosin filaments overlapped with actin filaments as well as nonoverlapped myosin filaments.
  • The H band is the region in which myosin does not overlap with actin.


During muscle contraction, the thin filaments slide over the thick filaments toward the M line, reducing the length of the H and I bands.  The A band always remains the same length.

Muscle fiber types and metabolism



Muscle fibers are arranged into a motor unit composed of the same fiber type, with each unit innervated by a single motor neuron.  Skeletal muscle fibers are categorized into 2 major types: type I (slow-twitch) and type II (fast-twitch) (

).

Type I (slow-twitch) fibers



Type I (slow-twitch) fibers specialize in stamina by using oxidative phosphorylation in the mitochondria for steady and sustained ATP production.  Type I fibers perform actions requiring low-level sustained force (eg, postural maintenance) and function primarily via aerobic metabolism, meaning they have high concentrations of myoglobin (oxygen storage) and mitochondria (aerobic respiration).  The high myoglobin content gives these fibers a red color.

Type II (fast-twitch) fibers



Type II (fast-twitch) fibers are specialized for generating rapid forceful movements; however, they fatigue quickly.  These fibers derive energy in the form of ATP mainly via glycogenolysis and subsequent anaerobic glycolysis.  The lower quantities of mitochondria and myoglobin lead to a pale color.



Histologically, these motor units form a characteristic mixed checkerboard pattern of type I and type II fibers.

Muscle contraction

Overview



  • Muscle contraction begins with a neural signal that initiates an action potential in the motor neuron.
  • The action potential leads to acetylcholine (ACh) release at the neuromuscular junction.
  • ACh binding to nicotinic receptors initiates an end-plate potential and muscle fiber depolarization.
  • Depolarization spreads along the sarcolemma and into transverse tubules, triggering calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR).
  • Intracellular calcium binds to troponin C, allowing for actin-myosin cross-bridge cycling.
  • ATP is required for both cross-bridge cycling and calcium reuptake into the SR during relaxation.

Excitation and action potential generation



Skeletal muscle is activated by lower motor neurons originating from the anterior horn of the spinal cord.  The motor neuron action potential leads to calcium influx at the axon terminal, promoting ACh vesicle fusion and release into the synaptic cleft.  ACh binds to postsynaptic nicotinic receptors (ionotropic or ligand-gated channels), causing sodium influx and potassium efflux.  The resultant end-plate potential, if suprathreshold, triggers a muscle action potential.



Muscle action potentials differ from neuronal action potentials in several key ways:



  • More negative resting membrane potential (~â€“90 mV vs ~â€“70 mV in neurons).
  • Slightly longer duration, which helps coordinate contraction.
  • Propagate into the fiber via transverse tubules (T-tubules), not just along the surface.


Like neurons, muscle action potentials are initiated by depolarization and rely on voltage-gated sodium and potassium channels for rapid upstroke and repolarization.  However, in skeletal muscle, the action potential propagates not only along the sarcolemma but also deep into the fiber via T-tubules, which are invaginations of the plasma membrane (

figure 2
).  T-tubules are closely associated with the SR, a specialized smooth endoplasmic reticulum that stores and releases calcium ions.  The T-tubules contain voltage-gated L-type calcium channels (dihydropyridine receptors [DHPRs]) that play a key role in the next step of muscle contraction, called excitation-contraction coupling.

Excitation-contraction coupling



Excitation-contraction coupling (ECC) refers to the process by which the electrical signal (muscle action potential) is translated into a mechanical response (contraction).  In skeletal muscle, this process works as follows:



  • The action potential in the T-tubules activates DHPRs, which undergo a conformational change.
  • DHPRs are mechanically linked to ryanodine receptor 1 (RyR1) on the SR membrane, and the conformational change in the DHPR triggers them to open.  This causes calcium release into the cytosol from the SR without requiring extracellular calcium influx.
  • Intracellular calcium binds to troponin C, causing tropomyosin to shift and expose myosin-binding sites on actin.
  • Actin-myosin cross-bridge cycling begins, powered by ATP hydrolysis, and results in contraction.


This tightly coordinated process ensures that every muscle fiber contracts uniformly in response to a single neural signal.

Actin-myosin cross-bridge cycling



Once calcium is released into the cytosol during ECC, it initiates a sequence of molecular interactions between actin and myosin filaments within the sarcomere.  This process, known as cross-bridge cycling, is driven by calcium binding and ATP hydrolysis and is responsible for the actual shortening of skeletal muscle fibers during contraction.  The actin-myosin interaction cycle consists of several ATP-dependent steps (

figure 3
):



  • Rest:  At rest, the myosin head is charged by ADP and inorganic phosphate (Pi) from previously bound and hydrolyzed ATP.  However, calcium-modulated regulatory complexes of troponin-C and tropomyosin block the myosin binding sites on actin.
  • Cross-bridge formation:  When calcium binds to troponin-C, troponin-tropomyosin complexes shift to expose the myosin binding sites; the myosin head then binds actin perpendicularly, forming a cross-bridge (
    figure 4
    ).
  • Power stroke:  The bound head releases Pi and bends the cross-bridge at a 45-degree angle, increasing filament overlap and shortening the sarcomere length.  Once the process is completed, ADP is released.
  • Cross-bridge dissociation:  A new ATP molecule must bind the myosin head to dissolve the crossbridge, returning the head to its original position to restart the cycle.
  • Cross-bridge cycling:  Continues while calcium and ATP are readily available; cycling across multiple myosin heads leads to increased or sustained contraction.


Muscle relaxation occurs when the stimulus for contraction ceases and calcium is actively removed from the cytosol.  Intracellular calcium is removed primarily via 2 pumps:



  • Na+/Ca2+ exchange pump (NCX):  NCX uses the large extracellular Na+ concentration gradient to pump Ca2+ out of the cell and, in the process, removes one intracellular Ca2+ in exchange for 3 extracellular Na+ ions.
  • Sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+-ATPase pump (SERCA):  SERCA is a Ca2+-ATPase pump that actively transfers Ca2+ from the cytosol to the lumen of SR at the expense of ATP hydrolysis.


The decline in cytosolic calcium causes tropomyosin to recover actin's binding sites, halting cross-bridge cycling and allowing the muscle to relax.

Muscle proprioceptors



Proprioceptors are specialized sensory receptors that provide the CNS with information about body position, movement, and muscle tension.  In skeletal muscle, the 2 primary proprioceptors are muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs (GTOs) (

figure 5
).

Muscle spindles



Muscle spindles (intrafusal muscle fibers) are stretch-sensitive receptors embedded within the muscle belly, parallel to the extrafusal (force-generating) muscle fibers.  They are innervated by group Ia and group II sensory axons and are sensitive to changes in muscle length.  Muscle spindles mediate the stretch (myotatic) reflex, which is commonly tested during the neurologic examination (deep tendon reflexes).  When a muscle is stretched, monosynaptic reflex activation of the alpha motor neuron (of the same muscle) results in contraction that resists the stretch.

Golgi tendon organs



GTOs are located at the junction between muscle fibers and tendons, innervated by group Ib afferent sensory axons.  GTOs are connected in series with contracting extrafusal skeletal muscle fibers.  When a muscle actively contracts against resistance, the increase in tension is transmitted through the tendon, activating the GTOs.  The Ib sensory axons from the GTOs contact inhibitory interneurons in the spinal cord, which in turn synapse with the alpha motor neurons that innervate the same muscle.  Therefore, the Golgi tendon circuit is a negative feedback system that regulates and maintains muscle tension.  When a muscle exerts too much force, the GTOs inhibit contraction of the muscle, causing sudden muscle relaxation.  This prevents damage to the musculoskeletal system.



Together, muscle spindles and GTOs continuously modulate reflexes and motor output, allowing for coordinated movement, posture maintenance, and injury prevention.

Skeletal muscle vs cardiac and smooth muscle



Whereas skeletal muscle is under voluntary control and contracts in response to somatic motor neuron stimulation, cardiac and smooth muscle differ in both structure and regulation:

Cardiac muscle



Cardiac muscle is also striated but contracts involuntarily.  In contrast to skeletal muscle ECC, cardiac ECC requires extracellular calcium.  During the action potential, calcium enters the myocyte through L-type calcium channels (DHPRs) in the T-tubules.  This influx triggers calcium-induced calcium release from the SR via RyR2, making both extracellular and intracellular calcium essential for contraction (

figure 6
).

Smooth muscle



Smooth muscle is nonstriated and contracts involuntarily.  It lacks organized sarcomeres and T-tubules.  Contraction is initiated by intracellular calcium increases, which can come from the SR or extracellular space.  Calcium binds calmodulin (calcium-modulated protein) because smooth muscle cells lack troponin.  Calmodulin activates myosin light-chain kinase to enable actin-myosin interaction.

Neuromuscular disorders



Several clinical conditions arise from abnormalities in muscle excitation or contraction:

Myasthenia gravis



Autoantibodies target nicotinic ACh receptors, reducing the number of functional receptors available for synaptic transmission.  This leads to decreased end-plate potentials and impaired muscle activation, particularly with sustained or repeated use, resulting in fluctuating weakness that classically affects ocular, bulbar, and proximal limb muscles.

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome



Antibodies inhibit voltage-gated calcium channels on the presynaptic terminal of motor neurons, impairing calcium influx and reducing ACh release into the synaptic cleft.  The decreased neurotransmitter availability weakens neuromuscular transmission, typically producing proximal muscle weakness and autonomic symptoms that may improve with repeated stimulation due to calcium buildup.

Malignant hyperthermia



Genetic mutations in RyR1 render the channel abnormally sensitive to certain anesthetic agents (eg, succinylcholine), resulting in uncontrolled calcium release from the SR.  The excess cytosolic calcium causes sustained muscle contraction and a hypermetabolic state with severe muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, acidosis, and potentially life-threatening complications if untreated.

Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy



This condition is caused by mutations in proteins involved in sarcolemmal stability and ECC (eg, caveolin, dysferlin).  Disruption of the T-tubule network and associated signaling leads to impaired propagation of depolarization across the muscle fiber.  As a result, calcium release becomes asynchronous, reducing coordinated contraction and causing progressive weakness in the shoulder and pelvic girdle muscles.

Summary



Skeletal muscle contraction is a multistep process dependent on action potential generation, intracellular calcium dynamics, and ATP-driven mechanical events.  The integration of electrical signaling and molecular motor activity enables skeletal muscle to generate controlled force.  The main steps involve the triggering of the muscle action potential by acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction, depolarization spreading through the sarcolemma into T-tubules, excitation-contraction coupling, and actin-myosin cross-bridge cycling.  Cardiac and smooth muscle differ in both structure and regulation.
